channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Anton Filatov, Ukrainian Film Critic, Drafted Into Real-Life War
item.description: Anton Filatov was pulled into a theater he never expected or wanted to enter: the front lines of war, where he now writes movingly of the scene in the trenches instead of what’s on the screen.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anton Filatov, left, a Ukrainian film critic turned soldier, in an abandoned house near the front in Donbas in August. He has kept writing throughout the war, though his subject has changed.

item.title: US Backs Immunity for Saudi Leader in Lawsuit Over Khashoggi Murder
item.description: The State Department said Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom’s de facto ruler, should have legal immunity as the head of the Saudi government.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Saudi Arabia in July. Prince Mohammed became prime minister in September, formalizing the power he had wielded for years as the country’s de facto ruler.

item.title: In France, Victims’ Fund Struggles to Heal Terrorism’s Traumas
item.description: At the trial over the 2016 terrorist attack in Nice, bereaved family members and survivors vent frustration at a cumbersome process to obtain compensation.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A makeshift memorial in 2016 for a terrorist attack in Nice, France. The trial, which is continuing, is intended to bring the victims a measure of comfort, clarity and catharsis.

item.title: Debris From Ruptured Nord Stream Pipelines Shows Traces of Explosives, Sweden Says
item.description: A series of undersea explosions ripped holes in the pipelines in late September, damaging the links that had been built to carry Russian natural gas to Germany.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Dutch Court Convicts 3 of Murder for 2014 Downing of Flight MH17 in Ukraine
item.description: The victim’s families drew some solace from the verdict, which placed responsibility for the tragedy squarely with Moscow, but the men found guilty may never be arrested.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The verdict session of the Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 trial near Amsterdam, on Thursday.

item.title: Wounded Iranian Protesters Forced to Flee and Heal in Hiding Abroad
item.description: Most who took part in antigovernment rallies try to stay below the radar in their own country, but some, particularly those injured in the crackdown, have been forced to flee.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Hawre Khalid for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masoud, 27, fled to Iraq after being shot and wounded during an antigovernment protest in Tehran.

item.title: Why Couldn’t South Korean Officials Stop the Halloween Disaster?
item.description: An analysis, based on official documents and parliamentary testimony, reveals that authorities in South Korea missed crucial chances to prevent a crowd crush that would kill 158 people.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene of the crowd crush in Seoul’s Itaewon neighborhood on Oct. 29. Poor coordination and communication delayed their response, records of the events show.

item.title: North Korea Launches Another ICBM, One of Its Most Powerful Yet
item.description: It was the latest in a series of increasingly provocative weapons tests in recent weeks, and drew condemnation from Japan and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: News coverage of North Korea’s latest missile launch in Tokyo on Friday.

item.title: 21 Killed in Fast-Moving Gaza Fire in Jabaliya Neighborhood
item.description: A family celebration turned deadly, and officials said that gasoline stored in an apartment fueled the fire and contributed to the high death toll.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: An apartment house was ravaged by fire in the Jabaliya neighborhood in the northern Gaza Strip on Thursday.

item.title: ‘Life Brought Me Here.’ Madagascar Adapts to a Changing Climate
item.description: Droughts, cyclones and floods have forced the people of Madagascar, a poor country in the southern Indian Ocean, to find new homes, new livelihoods and even new diets.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Joao Silva
item.media:description: Women on their way to a market in the town of Ambovambe, Madagascar, in June. When their crops failed, many farmers moved to Ambovambe.

item.title: Alaa Abd El Fattah, Egyptian Political Prisoner, Had Near-Death Experience, Family Says
item.description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, who is being given nutrients intravenously, told his relatives he collapsed in prison but planned to resume his hunger strike again.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest for Alaa Abd El Fattah in front of the British Embassy in Rome this month.

item.title: What Videos Show About the Extremes of China’s ‘Zero Covid’ Policy
item.description: A New York Times analysis examines the lengths China will go to eliminate Covid infections. Three years into the pandemic, China stands out in the harshness of its measures.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Isabelle Qian, Ang Li, Amy Chang Chien and Vivian Wang

item.title: UK Announces Billions in Tax Increases and Spending Cuts
item.description: The government is betting that the plan will put public finances back on sound footing but acknowledges that the measures are likely to deepen the economic misery for Britons.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Jeremy Hunt, the chancellor of the Exchequer, announced one of the most austere budgets ever imposed on Britain, which is already in a recession.

item.title: A Beloved Show Gets Another Life
item.description: The unexpected revival of “Neighbours,” the long-running drama that offered a sweet, uncontroversial vision of Australia, comes via Amazon. Will streaming change its nature?
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang

item.title: Taking on the Climate
item.description: International climate summits are imperfect, but they have led to real progress.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: COP27 climate conference in Egypt.

item.title: The End of Covid Vaccines at ‘Warp Speed’
item.description: Financial and bureaucratic barriers in the United States mean that the next generation of Covid vaccines may well be designed here, but used elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: While government funding helped to protect pharmaceutical companies in 2020 from the downsides of spending heavily on tricky vaccine research, there are no such assurances in 2022.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Three men have been found guilty of the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 and the murder of the 298 people onboard.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Anton Kotte, left, who lost his son, daughter-in-law and grandson in the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, hugs Piet Ploeg, whose brother, sister-in-law and nephew were killed, hug each other at the Schiphol Judicial Complex after the verdict on Thursday.

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 18, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Nov. 18, 2022.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: MH17 Convictions
item.description: Plus, Nancy Pelosi leaves leadership and the week in culture.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: A Dutch court on Thursday delivered its verdict in a the shooting down of a Malaysia Airlines passenger jet over eastern Ukraine in 2014, which killed all 298 people aboard.

item.title: The Surprising Afterlife of Unwanted Atom Bombs
item.description: The Biden administration has called for the retirement of the B83 superweapon, but nuclear experts say its most destructive parts will live on indefinitely in one form or another.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Retired nuclear weapons being readied for disassembly at the government’s Pantex plant near Amarillo, Texas, in 1996.

item.title: Brittney Griner Transferred to Russian Penal Colony, Lawyers Say
item.description: The W.N.B.A. star, who has been detained in Russia since February, is facing nine years in a Russian prison on a drug charge.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the U.S. basketball star, being escorted to court in August in Khimki, Russia.

item.title: Lab-Grown Meat Receives Clearance From F.D.A.
item.description: In a first step toward cultivated meat reaching dinner tables and restaurant menus, regulators said that a start-up company’s chicken was safe to eat.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Gabriela Hasbun for The New York Times
item.media:description: A chicken dish featuring lab-grown meat from Upside Foods, the company whose product received regulatory clearance.

item.title: What to Know As UK Unveils Budget Proposal
item.description: The government’s budget proposal, known as the Autumn Statement, will lead to £55 billion in tax rises and spending cuts to fill a massive funding gap. Here are five takeaways.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The budget proposal comes as Britain is experiencing the highest surge in consumer prices in more than four decades.

item.title: Meet the ‘Closer’ Who Finds the Right Words When Climate Talks Hit a Wall
item.description: Sue Biniaz is considered one of the most innovative American legal minds when it comes to climate negotiations. She once rescued a collapsing deal by using quotation marks.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Frances F. Denny for The New York Times

item.title: Alexei Navalny Says He Has Been Placed in Permanent Solitary Confinement
item.description: The Russian opposition leader has been jailed since March 2021 after surviving an assassination attempt that American intelligence agencies blamed on Russian security agents.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Alina Lobzina and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Aleksei Navalny in court in Moscow last year.

item.title: Dutch Court Convicts 3 Men Over Downing of MH17 Plane in 2014
item.description: The verdict offers a bare measure of justice for the 298 people killed in the downing of the jet, but it may set an example for possible prosecutions of Russian crimes during the current war.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Dutch court on Thursday delivered its verdict in a the shooting down of a Malaysia Airlines passenger jet over eastern Ukraine in 2014, which killed all 298 people aboard.

item.title: What the Unusual Midterm Elections Mean for Climate Action
item.description: A split Congress makes it unlikely that Republicans will undo Biden’s climate legislation, but they’re likely to try to slow it. There may also be room for agreement on infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Despite the divided Congress, Republicans and Democrats both say they hope to advance a bill that would make it easier to build energy infrastructure.

item.title: Myanmar Frees Former UK Envoy Victoria Bowman and Others in Amnesty
item.description: Among those released were Victoria Bowman, the former diplomat, and Sean Turnell, an Australian economic adviser to Myanmar’s imprisoned civilian leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: A bus carrying prisoners who were released from Insein prison arrives in Yangon, Myanmar, on Thursday.

item.title: Why the Crypto Collapse Matters
item.description: The failure of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX put the entire industry under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: FTX’s founder, Sam Bankman-Fried.

item.title: Russian Attacks on Ukraine’s Power Grid Endanger Nuclear Plants, U.N. Agency Says
item.description: The director of the International Atomic Energy Agency called the effect of the strikes on the energy grid “very concerning.”
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: For months, worries about a nuclear safety have centered on the southern Zaporizhzhia power plant, which attacks have repeatedly disconnected from Ukraine’s grid.

item.title: 25 Travel Experiences That Should Be on Your Bucket List
item.description: A pair of internationally minded writers, a chef, an architect and a landscape photographer made a list of the most extraordinary adventures a person should seek out. Here are the results.
item.dc:creator: Alwa Cooper, Ashlea Halpern, Debra Kamin, Aileen Kwun, Miguel Morales, Dan Piepenbring and Michael Snyder
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: What to Expect From the U.K.’s Budget Proposals Today
item.description: Tax increases and spending cuts are expected as the government tries to stabilize its finances and reassure financial markets.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: “I’ve been explicit that taxes are going to go up,” the chancellor of the Exchequer, Jeremy Hunt, said recently.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Tensions over a missile blast in Poland are easing after an investigation that suggested it was an accident.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Polish Police, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Polish police showing forensic experts investigating the site where a missile hit.

item.title: A Timeline of Events in the MH17 Plane Crash Investigation
item.description: The disaster claimed 298 civilian lives, and came in the midst of a conflict that foreshadowed Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Malaysian air crash investigator with the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, near Grabovo, Ukraine, in 2014.

item.title: A Dutch court is delivering a verdict in the MH17 crash, which killed 298 people.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wreckage from Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in a field near Grabovo, Ukraine, in 2014.

item.title: For Ukraine, Keeping the Lights On Is One of the Biggest Battles
item.description: This week’s missile assault by Russian forces has hit at least 15 energy facilities — some for the fifth or sixth time — forcing controlled blackouts in every part of the country.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Employees working last week to repair a transformer at an electrical substation damaged by a Russian missile strike in central Ukraine.

item.title: Corrections: Nov. 17, 2022
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Nov. 17, 2022.

item.title: ‘This Is Not Ukraine’s Fault’: Tensions Ease Over Missile Strike in Poland
item.description: NATO and Polish officials said that it was a Ukrainian missile that crossed the border and killed two people, but that Russia bore the blame.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Polish soldiers installing barbed wire along the Polish border with the Russian exclave of Kaliningrad on Wednesday.

item.title: In a Polish Village, Renewed Fears of War Spilling Over From Ukraine
item.description: When missiles landed a few miles from the Ukrainian border, residents say they reignited fears that had largely calmed since the war’s early weeks.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: Searching for missile wreckage on farmland in the Polish village of Przewodow, near the border with Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Electrical Cords, Metal Pipes: In Kherson, Signs of Torture Emerge
item.description: The liberation of a Russian-held city was joyous. The revelations about what happened during occupation are anything but.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of the Ukrainian security forces in a basement used as a prison by occupying Russian forces.

item.title: Study: West African Floods 80 Times More Likely by Climate Change
item.description: Amid the ‘loss and damage’ debate at global climate talks, the study adds to evidence that less-developed countries suffer from warming that industrialized nations largely cause.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Groceries being delivered to a relief camp in Rivers State, Nigeria, in October.

item.title: A New Focus on Jona Ostiglio, a Jewish Artist Who Broke Barriers
item.description: Fresh research into the life of Jona Ostiglio, a hitherto unknown 17th-century Jewish artist, reveals a unique painter who lived outside set boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: “Landscape With People, Palazzo Pitti,” by Jona Ostiglio. The professional painter worked in Florence for some of the city’s most powerful families at a time when Jews were not normally given such opportunities.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Crisis Averted?
item.description: Leaders call an explosion in Poland an “unfortunate accident.” Plus, Tuvalu’s “digital twin.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Police investigators on Wednesday near the site of missile strikes in Przewodow, Poland, a day earlier.

item.title: The Fatal Blast in Poland Shows the Heightened Risk of Escalation
item.description: The hasty and likely inaccurate reactions from some countries to the apparent explosion of a missile was worrisome, but so is Russia’s nuclear temptation in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Polish soldiers installing a barbed wire fence along the Polish border with the Russian exclave of Kaliningrad on Wednesday.

item.title: UK Sees Varied Domestic Threats, Mainly From Iran, Russia and China
item.description: In an annual assessment, the head of MI5 also cited Iranian attempts to kill or kidnap at least 10 critics of Iran’s government.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Ken McCallum, the director general of Britain’s MI5 security service, discussed domestic security threats during an address at Thames House in Central London on Wednesday.

item.title: What We Know About the Missile Involved in the Poland Blast
item.description: Both Russia and Ukraine have depended on the S-300 systems, which are built by Russia, as protection against incoming air assaults during the ongoing war.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: An S-300 missile launch during a military exercise in Greece in 2013.

item.title: Article 4 and Article 5 of the NATO Treaty Explained
item.description: The provisions are core parts of the NATO charter, but are not often invoked.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Poland’s president, Andrzej Duda, speaking to reporters in Warsaw on Wednesday. The government has so far refrained from turning to the Article 4 provision of NATO’s treaty.

item.title: Small Polish Town Becomes the Center of Attention After Missile Blast
item.description: Poland’s president said that a Ukrainian air defense missile had most likely caused a deadly blast there on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Ada Petriczko
item.media:description: Police investigators on Wednesday near the site of missile strikes in Przewodow, Poland, a day earlier.

item.title: Expectations Run High as an Exuberant Lula Speaks at Climate Summit
item.description: On Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s first trip abroad after winning last month’s election, he pledged to protect the Amazon rainforest and said Brazil was “leaving its cocoon.”
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Brazil’s president-elect, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, was swarmed at the United Nations climate conference in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, on Wednesday.

item.title: As Netanyahu Nears Power, the Far Right Wants to Oversee the Army
item.description: Bezalel Smotrich is an ultranationalist who opposes Palestinian sovereignty and wants to govern Israel by Jewish law. He seeks the Defense Ministry in Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bezalel Smotrich, center, with his team before a press briefing in Ramat Gan, Israel, in October. Mr. Smotrich is hoping to become defense minister in a Netanyahu government.

item.title: Xi Scolds Trudeau Over Private Conversation Gone Public
item.description: The exchange, in which China’s leader accused the Canadian leader of leaking details of a brief conversation they had, happened at the end of a summit in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Adam Scotti/Prime Minister’s Office, via Reuters

item.title: With a Missed Cancer Diagnosis, Vicky Phelan Exposed a Scandal
item.description: Ireland is mourning Vicky Phelan, who died this week. She became an advocate for women after a Pap smear that had been deemed negative turned out to be positive.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:credit: Niall Carson/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vicky Phelan, the patient whose case triggered a cervical cancer screening controversy, in Dublin in 2018. She died on Monday.

item.title: New Measure of Climate’s Toll: Disasters Are Now Common Across US
item.description: A new report found that 90 percent of all counties nationwide have suffered a major disaster since 2011.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: Members of the fire department in Jackson, Ky., patrolling the downtown after torrential rains brought devastating floods this summer.

item.title: Divided Government
item.description: A split Congress could lead to government shutdowns and economic turmoil.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Capitol on Monday.

item.title: A Clash Over Degrees: How Hot Should Nations Allow the Earth to Get?
item.description: The mantra has been: Limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius or risk climate catastrophe. But at COP27, there are hints of backsliding.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer, David Gelles and Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Protesters at the United Nations climate summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, on Saturday.

item.title: G20 Summit Ends With Sanctions on Russia Still Dividing Some Countries
item.description: The meeting did not result in the customary joint communiqué, and the “leaders’ declaration” issued instead noted “different assessments” of the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: As the Group of 20 summit in Bali drew to a close on Wednesday, President Joko Widodo of Indonesia, right, handed a gavel to Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India.

item.title: Lockdowns Set Off Rare Protest in Guangzhou in China
item.description: Weary migrants thronged a street in the manufacturing hub of Guangzhou to protest food shortages and lengthy stay-at-home orders under China’s strict “zero-Covid” policy.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and John Liu
item.media:description: People protesting in Guangzhou, China, in November, in this still image obtained from a video.
